awd_titl_txt: Explaining Low Crime Rates in Immigrant Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The literature has produced several noteworthy findings on the relationship between immigration and crime.  One of the most robust findings is: areas, and especially neighborhoods, with greater concentrations of immigrants have lower rates of crime. Yet important areas of inquiry remain. For example, extant research lumps all immigrants together and neglects important differences across groups. Moreover, theories on the connection between crime and immigration have not been sufficiently empirically evaluated, thus there is not a clear understanding about why immigrant communities are some of the safest places around.  Despite a rapidly expanding cross-sectional literature, research examining the longitudinal immigration-crime nexus across areas has been scarce, making it a challenge to determine the proper causal ordering between crime and immigration. The goal of the proposed project in light of the research evidence which finds that immigrant concentration typically reduces levels of neighborhood crime  is to better understanding why this occurs.  
 
The research team examines the immigration-crime nexus in neighborhoods across the Southern California metropolitan region over a decade (2000-2010). Using data from a variety of sources, the investigators' analyses, first, will unpack immigration in order to capture the rich diversity that exists, including grouping immigrants by similar racial/ethnic categories, by areas or regions of the world they emigrate from, and by where immigrants co-locate once in the U.S.   The investigators will compare these approaches with the typical approach employed in studies examining just the percent foreign born. Second, to begin to better understand why immigrant communities are some of the safest places around, they empirically evaluate several competing theoretical explanations hypothesized to account for lower crime rates in immigrant neighborhoods. And finally, in contrast to much of the extant literature, the research team takes a dynamic approach to the study of crime and immigration by examining changes in neighborhoods across the cities in the Southern California region.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the proposed project was to examine the immigration-crime nexus in neighborhoods across the Southern California metropolitan region over a decade (2000-2010). This research builds on the existing literature in significant ways.

First, we proposed unpacking immigration in order to capture the rich diversity that exists, including grouping immigrants by similar racial/ethnic categories, by areas or regions of the world they emigrate from, and by where immigrants co-locate once in the U.S. We compared these approaches with the typical approach employed in studies—examining just the percent foreign born. These analyses addressed a variety of research questions including: How robust is the immigration-crime relationship? What are the appropriate ways to capture varied effects of immigrant groups on neighborhood crime rates? Do immigrant groups from different countries of origin have similar or dissimilar effects on neighborhood crime rates? Which immigrant groups have crime reducing effects in neighborhoods? Which have crime enhancing effects? Findings from the analyses are reported in our study, “Different than the Sum of its Parts: Examining the Unique Impacts of Immigrant Groups on Neighborhood Crime Rates” published in the Journal of Quantitative Criminology 34:1-36.

Second, to begin to better understand why immigrant communities are some of the safest places around, we empirically evaluated several competing theoretical explanations hypothesized to account for lower crime rates in immigrant neighborhoods. In particular, using data on voluntary organizations in neighborhoods from the National Center for Charitable Statistics (NCCS), we examined the role that local institutions may play in accounting for lower crime rates in immigrant neighborhoods, paying particular attention to immigrant- or ethnic-serving institutions. Moreover, using data on the locations and types of all businesses in the area, we compared one type of immigrant community—ethnic enclaves—with non-enclave immigrant communities to determine whether lower crime rates in immigrant neighborhoods are mostly a function of strong economic organization. Findings from the analyses are reported in the study, "Institutional Completeness and Crime in Immigrant Neighborhoods," forthcoming in the Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency.

And third, in new research we are considering how immigration impacts race- and ethnic-specific offending and victimization levels, and seek to answer  the following questions: (1) Are immigrants associated with lower rates of both community victimization and offending within their overall racial group? (2) Are these effects similar for within and between group crime? (3) Do these results vary by crime type? (4) Are these results consistent across groups?

To answer these questions, we use data from the 2000 U.S. Census, offender and victim specific crime counts from the Los Angeles Police department (2000-2002), and employment data from Reference USA. We then use negative binomial regression to model rates of victimization and offending within Los Angeles egohoods for two of L.A.’s largest demographic groups - Asians and Hispanics. Egohoods were constructed with a .75-mile radius buffer around block centroids, creating rolling averages based on values of block centroids contained within this buffer zone. Three-year crime totals for robberies and assaults were then constructed based on 5 possible victim and offender racial compositions: (1) Hispanic victims with any other group as the offender, (2) Hispanic offenders with any other group as the victim, (3) Hispanic victims with any non-Hispanic offender, (4) Hispanic offenders with any non-Hispanic victim, and (5) Hispanic victims with a Hispanic offender. This same process was followed for Asian models, with multiple controls included for characteristics of neighborhood social disorganization.

The results of the Hispanic models show a significant positive association between immigration and assault overall (outcomes 1 and 2), though this relationship becomes negative in the inter-group (outcomes 3 and 4) and intra-group (outcome 5) models. Robbery models show a similar pattern to assaults, though with one key difference- Hispanic immigrants are associated with an increase in Hispanic inter-group robbery victimization. In the case of Asian assault, Asian immigration has a negative effect on victimization and offending across all outcomes. This association holds for the combined models when looking at robbery, though Asian immigration has a positive effect on Asian inter-group and intra-group victimization. Rates of inter-group Asian offending were to small for the model to converge. These results show that the effects of immigration on crime vary by the group being studied, the type of crime committed, and victim and offender compositions.

Though all of the dissemination of findings, including to non-academic audiences, we hope to disspell many of the myths associated with immigrant criminality and immigration and crime. Popular perception is that immigrants are more crime-prone than their native-born counterparts and that immigration to an area causes crime to rise but our research does not support these claims and instead attempts to explain why crime rates are so low in immigrant communities.
